title: When will 25,000 or more fans next attend a Premier League match?
preds:
While there has been some expermints in letting people in to venues, like for the snooker final in Shelfield. These expermints have not been large enough or analysed,
to change the Govement's position on opening up the grounds for a large number of fans (25000) into a Premier League match before 24th May, so I've back 100% No.
Entry with test or vaccine certificate

Boris has confirmed that on final day of seasons (May 23), if progress made EPL will be able to host max of 1/4 of statium capacity or 10K. Old Tr has 74K capacity, so 1/4 of that is less than 25K.  https://theathletic.com/news/premier-league-fans-stadiums-may/jmec5rXSm27Q
The League continues to be cautious in exposing fans to the pandemic.

Houston Astros game in America came close even with a promise to keep the limit under 25% capacity. Between 20 and 25 thousand actually attended, which I presume was over 25% capacity. This sort of proxy sporting event could happen but again, the overall consensus says not before May 24, which is rational to me at this time.

No major news on this, so I think it is unlikely.  The crowd forecast of 0% seems crazy though.  Revising down to 7%. Note that there is reportedly a FA cup final allowing 21k fans on May 15th.  Doesn't count for this question, but it is a test case.  Things are loosening up. https://www.thesun.co.uk/sport/football/14542695/fa-cup-final-attendance-fans-carabao-cup-wembley/

Latest update on COVID certification trial events, including the FA cup final on May 17, which is slated to go beyond the current 10,000 limit set for event reopening (hosting 21,000 or 23% of Wembley’s capacity). https://www.theguardian.com/football/2021/apr/04/wembley-covid-test-events-fa-cup-carabao-cup Even with the uncertainty involved in this actually going ahead (this government's track record on managing certification schemes and electronic record keeping is not strong, lots of "message testing" going on in UK press from both sides of the vaccination passport debate and don’t confuse vaccinated population with first dose figures) this "test number" comes in below the question’s 25,000 threshold.
Amazing progress has been made in British vaccinations and may speed up this type of reopening.

Any potential test of this magnitude would probably need to get announced within the next couple of weeks.
Still theres time left to organise this...
As most of the UK adults will be vaccinated by the middle of May, a vaccine passport will allow vaccinated people to attend the games.  This will allow resumption of mass attendance to soccer games.

"The following stage, scheduled for 17 May, would allow stadia to open with a 25% capacity limit, up to a maximum of 10,000 spectators. The current plan is then for all restrictions on social contact to be lifted on 21 June."
- BBC quoting Culture Secretary.

Looks like 10k per game in last two rounds in May before easing restrictions further in June. Not likely that the vaccine roll out moves this date up. https://www.goal.com/en/news/fans-could-return-to-premier-league-stadiums-for-final-two/5tq32821r6161mkvvjxw3tnll

talk of an experiment with 10k people.
25k really feels like a stretch
The UK Gov. doesn't expect to have everything laxed until at least June - among other factors other forecasters have outlined.

BBC is reporting up to 10k fans to be allowed before the end of the season:
https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/56381482 10k is not 25k...so seems very unlikely that they will make it to 25k.  But, you never know, if the vaccine rollout continues moving forward. Putting it at 15% for now, will revise down as the time gets closer

Ok so likely there's not enough time left to organise this for next weekend :)
Still i don't think it's completely impossible to have something before end of may but i will continue the practise of averaging out my take with that of the market for OOC calls: 10&1 = a generous 6
There will be no appetite for crowded stadiums until we are much farther along on this programme.

Current rates are still high and with variants and vaccine roll out pace, I don’t think public officials have the appetite to even consider public events like attending football matches for a few more months, at least not more than maybe 10-20% of most stations capacity, which are generally 30-60K, so 3-12K spectators.

"Stadiums would be able to host 10,000 fans or 25 per cent of their capacity — whichever is smaller — from May 17."
https://theathletic.com/news/premier-league-fans-fixtures-move/5IJFx09LPN9j

With the latest four-step lockdown restrictions timetable from 23rd February:
-Assumption - Premier league matches will not fall under the 'Outdoor Sports facilities/grassroots sporting games' easing scheduled for 29th March earliest
-Assumption - Access and Egress from the stadiums will be more difficult to handle than socially distancing fans in their seating
-Allowing for distancing of 1.5-2M between fans could require 3-4 seats empty between fans on each row, and 2 empty rows between seated rows [ https://parametricmonkey.com/2017/10/23/seating-bowl/ ]
-Only 3 or 4  UK stadiums have capacity of approx 75000 or more and still would struggle to seat 25000 fans under current social contact limitations
-Current social contact limitations will not be lifted before 21st June, under the recent revisions
Looks like it will only be 10k. Left some flex for a “trial event” or other revision

My only concern now is that Boris surprises us with allowing a bigger crowd 'based on data'. It's looking likely Man City will be winning the league on 23 May - a city that Boris might want to scoop away from Labour.

Boris Johnson announces May 17th as the earliest fans will be allowed back into the stadiums, but that this will be limited to 10,000 people. It seems almost certain that we won't see 25,000 fans in a stadium until the next season. https://talksport.com/football/838421/boris-johnson-football-fans-return-date-premier-league-lockdown/
Recent policy announcement states only 10,000 fans by mid-May 2021
Confirmed today: Maximum 10,000 fans or 25% capacity (whatever is lowest) after 17th May at the earliest.

Carabao Cup final April 25 and FA Cup final May 15 to best used as test events for larger summer events [1]. 
Premier League chief hopeful that fans can attend games by the end of the season [2]. However, given social distance restrictions, attendance would be limited.  [1] https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/plan-to-bring-back-fans-for-fa-cup-and-carabao-cup-finals-5bq83r98p?utm_medium=Social&utm_source=Twitter#Echobox=1613412458
[2] https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/56112794 Thanks @Michael-Bennett for the links
Times front page article today suggests it will be close. Leaving unchanged.
Locking it in at 100% for "Not before 24 May 2021"
https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/56112794 - No hopeful comments from Premier League chief. He hopes for 'some fans' in the title winning stadium on 26 May. 1% left for a 'Boris surprise'.
If the leaked roadmap is to be believed...

As forecasted, large crowds look set to be reserved for FA Cup Final  https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/plan-to-bring-back-fans-for-fa-cup-and-carabao-cup-finals-5bq83r98p?utm_medium=Social&utm_source=Twitter#Echobox=1613412458
The same rationale as before, no PL stadia can handle 25000 socially distanced fans. Social distancing is almost certainly going to be a feature until the summer at least.

Moving up to 100% with UK Govt's "optimistic" announcement for over 50's vaccinated by May 21 [1 & 2]. Reliability of such statements vs the current UK Government's record of COVID management successes is not strong, but even if this is true the average age of a season ticket holder is in 40's [3]. Therefore prospects of any lifting before May, combined with previous analysis of stadiums and distancing requirements (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1212668), moves into the incredible space. [1]: https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-55961387
[2]: https://www.ft.com/content/0760ffe8-b76b-460e-8c24-dda0e73e71d8
[3]: https://thefsa.org.uk/news/football-clubs-facing-demographic-time-bomb/#:~:text=Figures%20released%20by%20the%20Premier,of%20the%20game%20in%20future.

Adjusting by 1% to May following BJs new found cautiousness in the management of expectations for reopening at this afternoon's COVID briefing (link to follow). Vaccine rollout suggests 1st vaccine dose offered to the majority by May 21 which leaves a large scale opening of entertainment venues extremely unlikely within the frame of this question. The governments outward cautiousness in the face of leading questions from right wing press outlets and willingness to resist the implied criticism of "over caution" by some of the more libertarian hard liners (potentially contrived)  is a strong indicator of the Governments wish to be seen to act in line with the publics cautious sentiment. As such, and given the previous baseline analysis (https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1212668), anything of this scale before May 21 seems a remote possibility.

Shifting to a more positive position on my understanding that there has been the introduction of new fast testing in the UK. I'm not endorsing these "lateral flow tests" (1), but the sense of safety such a high level of testing will give people is capable of opening up stadium doors. 1. https://www.bbc.com/news/health-55751874
Vaccination plan does not allow it before
Always a possibility that vaccinations can be increased and that lateral flow testing will be piloted at the end of the season (although preseason more likely for piloting)

The vaccine roll-out will not cover the population to a sufficient level by end May.
There are a handful of stadiums that can possibly hold 25,000 spectators with sufficient social distancing. Regardless of this, encouraging that amount of people to descend on a small vicinity at the same time will not be encouraged

Very few stadia can plausibly get to 25,000 with plausible social distancing - and the ones that are are in cities that are or have been struggling with the pandemic recently: the leaders in Newcastle, Manchester, Liverpool and London are not going to be pushing hard for reopening.  The 2 per cent, however, reflects the chance of the UK govt doing something quixotic and a few matches sneaking through.

The UK response to Covid has been a mess. There is not a chance in hell it will be possible to safely allow that many people return to games. Especially as the break even cost of opening up a stadium to the public requires a significant amount of fans for it to make sense - in Old Trafford etc.

with 8th march being the earliest date before any plan on opening up is presented and schools being first etc...it is inconceivable that any prem game will see in effect 25-50%. Even Man utd with 74,000 capacity would need to allow  1/3rd in. Last Autumn, maximum was 2,000 after a reasonable open summer for the economy.

Outbreak has canceled/delayed several games already, vaccine rollout on track in UK, but PL not getting special access.   https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/uk-sports/2020/12/31/premier-league-rules-out-private-supplies-of-coronavirus-vaccine-for-clubs/
Not enough time for the vaccination of the general population to take effect.
Vaccine rollout going well but feels like there will be caution on easing.
New update about the coronavirus in Japan 4 days ago

We will need to see several consecutive weeks of dramatic reductions in cases and hospitalisations before fans are allowed to return to large sporting events. Social distancing measures look likely to be implemented when fans do return, leading to reduced capacity. It appears unlikely enough will change before the end of the 2020/21 season for attendances of 25,000 to be made possible. 2% possibility provided for 16 March - 23 May due to possibility of government adopting an aggressive reopening strategy in March and April as the vaccine rollout takes effect and pressure from the Treasury grows.

Adjusting forecast by 3% based on latest projections for general population over 18 vaccination plans (current UK Gov forecast September 2021). Covid-19: Beating September vaccine target for all over-18s a 'bonus' - Raab https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-55694967

Under UK law currently fans are restricted depending on the tier they fall into. This will not allow 25,000 until COVID law changes.  Do not see this happening before this season is over. But there is a lot of time and with vaccine role out and summer coming to hopefully help with the spread there is still a small chance, but I see the EPL taking it slow and not jumping to much past the 4,000 mark.  Tier 1: A maximum of 4,000 fans or 50 percent capacity, whichever is less.
Tier 2: A maximum of 2,000 fans or 50 percent capacity, whichever is less.
Tier 3: No fans will be allowed entry into stadiums. https://soccer.nbcsports.com/2020/12/14/london-premier-league-covid-fans/

Covid vaccinations will need to be in the large majority of the population before this can happen. Also we don't yet know the ecological validity of the vaccine on a mass scale, only its efficacy in test trials. We need the vaccine to have been administered to people in the age brackets of 30-50. Average age of a premier league football fan is 41. That is currently estimated by Omni calc to be July at the earliest with 1m vaccines a week. Highly unlikely this will be allowed. I bloody hope it will be allowed again one day!

25,000 is a large number of fans, and no stadium in the Premier League could maintain a number of fans that large with social distancing. The government has promised we will be "back to normal" by Easter, but such promises are worth little. Also, large events will be the last thing to return to normal. If the vaccine rollout goes particularly well, or if cases really drop off, we may have 25,000 fans back in the stadium as normal. However, it's more likely they will use the FA Cup as the big "back to stadiums" event, and start larger attendances next season.

1) Premier League calendar: The season will end very shortly after full restrictions are lifted (end of March). The start of April is game week 30 out of 38. Will the premier league see it worth allowing fans back in large capacity for 8 game weeks? I think not.  2) Only 7 clubs in the premier league have a capacity above 50,000. The largest is 75,000. Fresh out of COVID restrictions, social distancing will still need to be maintained to a degree. To allow for 25,000 fans, a stadium would need at the very least a capacity of 100,000 for it to be considered. There are currently no stadiums with this capacity. For this to happen, the largest stadium in the league would need to be full to 1/3 of capacity. I don't this is realistic at all.
The current lockdown and the continued surge and slow role out of Covid vaccinations mean this is a low likelihood.

lockdown will have a huge impact on lowering numbers, but large crowds will likely remain limited to prevent another spike.  The vaccine will likely not have an effect by late May due to the slow rollout.

Looking ever more unlikely. Lockdown until mid-Feb at least. Even allowing for relaxations, test events with ~1-2k are not happening before March and then you have to wait for results. And that assumes the season does not get cancelled.

Mild adjustment made after UK Gov announcement of lockdown which might adjust case numbers (and buy space for vaccination programme to kick in) such that pre-May match attendance of 25,000+. Low probability at this stage (pending data on lockdown effect on case numbers in 3 weeks time) but possible so worthy of (slight) adjustment. See previous forecast for starting point analysis (if interested!):  https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1212668
The current pace of vaccination in the UK make me a bit more optimistic than the crowd

This lockdown should be seen as a positive for post-Match baskets because it will reduce rates and relieve over-burdened hospitals by then. However, it does point to the issue of opening up slowly and letting the vaccination program work without compromising it with large social events. Mid-Feb reopening... then wait two weeks to see the effects of reopening (schools/gyms/sports) on R rate takes us to March. All being well, March leads to further reopening (restaurants/pubs/some crowds).  Mass testing in place in schools for end of February. No reason that can't be rolled out for pre-games at stadiums by that time with all the financial power of the Premier League. Even still, pilots and incremental return would be the sensible route. Very touch and go between the last two baskets but I'm forecasting a cautious approach from the government this time...

New national lockdown "until February 15th at least" suggests a return to large social gatherings will be pushed back by at least six weeks. During this time the rate of infection will likely slow while vaccine inoculations increase, which should improve the situation in the UK. But administering the vaccine to 25MM labeled priority will likely take longer. Guessing that fans returning to games will be limited to less than <33% before May.

Thanks to @Michael-Bennett for the analytical assist: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1212630
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1212659 Adjusting 5% with the solid logic argument that no stadium in the UK is capable of achieving a socially distanced (est. 20% capacity: https://voxeu.org/article/spread-covid-19-and-attending-football-matches-england) match that would reach a 25,000 fan capacity.* This leaves the only route to this questions resolution a successful and rapid COVID vaccination programme for the UK population (66.6 million) that would allow such mass gatherings having reached "herd immunity". Assuming a herd immunity threshold similar to Polio (WHO: https://www.who.int/news-room/q-a-detail/herd-immunity-lockdowns-and-covid-19) of 80% this would require 53.28 million people successfully vaccinated. Even with the "adapted" vaccination programme proposed by the UK in the first week of 2021 UK Gov planning is targeting "at risk" population as a priority between March and April 21 (UK Gov est. 25 million people: https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-55274833).  This also assumes such planning will go according to the plan (current UK Gov do not have a good record on this front!). As such, achievement by UK Gov planning of herd immunity threshold to let general population attend football matches (even those as financially important as Prem League) seems extremely low. As always, challenges to argument and assumptions very welcome! *and assuming that Spain isn't likely to let the UK Prem League use Camp Nou (cap 99,354) in 2021 for a thousand reasons!

As at 4th Jan 21:  current COVID R rate in UK (1.1 - 1.3: https://www.gov.uk/guidance/the-r-number-in-the-uk#latest-r-number-and-growth-rate), combined with new variant (R rate impact in region of +0.4 or higher) and growing pessimism with vaccine availability and roll out speed make such an obvious "high risk" allowances highly unlikely (given current societal attitudes to UK government COVID management). April season for the Premier League is busy however (https://www.premierleague.com/news/1754980) and pressure may mount to allow season ticket holders to attend if vaccination proof can be provided and stadium size can allow for social distancing measures to be in place.  Stadiums capable of such measures would be teams with major fixtures in April 21, and assuming an equal number of tickets would be shared amongst both sides (12,500 each) this is not an impossible scenario to envisage (but unlikely). Money and income considerations will likely be driving lobbying efforts, but there are no signs at this moment that UK government are giving weight to such voices over general population concerns and other priorities (schools, restaurants and pubs etc.). With a successful vaccine roll out programme between Feb and March however this questions scenario may be possible for VERY specific fixtures.

I agree that next season is most likely, although I do think it's possible we may see crowds this season if the vaccine rollout is successful. They may want to trial crowds ahead of Euros, plus there could be pressure from title winning club wanting to lift trophy in front of their fans.

Vaccination program is being limited because they want partial (one dose) vaccination for many rather than total vaccination for few. Mass testing is the route to crowds but with Tier 4 a new thing, schools closing, and PM talking about tougher restrictions, crowds at football games is a huge stretch right now. Will update after flu season.

This looks more of a stretch. Given the number of games postponed in the last few days, there is a not insignificant chance of a circuit breaker in the PL. 25,000+ fans at this time feels a long way away.
New Covid strain in the UK complicates prospects even more.

I assume that the government will wait until everyone receives their second dose. The recommended time difference between first and second is approximately 21 days. But the numbers quoted are between 4 and 12 weeks, which is 1-3 months.  I am updating my prediction to show that it will be likely well after May 24.

Sports Ground Safety Guidelines 20-33% capacity. Max 2-3 of stadiums that can hold 25k fans at those levels. Most of those stadiums are located in high density areas (ie London, Manchester). Sports Ground Safety Guidelines would need re-evaluation to increase attendance. Recent high profile Covid cancellation Man City vs Everton. Not directly related to attendance, but provides some negative fodder against govt leadership returning to large capacity.  Centralized distribution guesstimate (roughly mirrors US expecations in GJ public forecast 2/3's population ) by July-August. Assuming uniform innoculation rate by month.( Wondering how 30 day gap between double shots will affect progress towards "herd immunity"? Not that this level of immunity is critical for increased attendance levels.) Potential use of verified "Covid passports" might increase chances of larger scale attendance. First phases of distribution are older population and thus less likely to attend public events under normal conditions.
Infections increasing in UK as nee strain emerges. Will review in a few weeks to see impacts of immunisation data

Feels very unlikely we will be talking about further easings before 15th March given the current situation. It feels likely that the UK will have a very decent proportion of the population vaccinated by then if AZ is approved given there are 50m person doses purchased and reading across from the Pfizer announced delivery timeline in the us (cannot find one for AZ). It feels like things have to go very well though for the UK to have reached herd immunity and that to be verified to the extent people are willing to open up higher risk things. Perhaps 10 - 25% chance reached 60% vaccinated by late April, but perhaps only a 20 - 50% chance that is enough for her immunity and I think only 10- 20% chance that is going to be recognised and the Government wants to quickly move to that scale of reopening. That gives somewhere between 0 - 3%. Perhaps more likely I think more like 80% chance that all the vulnerable individuals are vaccinated by the end of Q1. That may mean that people are willing to open up early on the basis of low hospitalisations. Call that 20 - 50% which gets you to 16 - 40%. Mid of the range would be 37% but overall I think caution is called for given high cases loads at the moment and that this is a “tight” deadline. Therefore going with 25% for March - May.

Thanks to Averroes' great analysis of PL stadium capacities, where he points out that only Man Utd's Old Trafford stadium would exceed 25,000 fans at 33% capacity. [1] However, according to this article, "Manchester United have modified Old Trafford to accommodate 23,500 socially distanced spectators." [2] So even at highest capacity stadium, social distancing prevents 25,000 fans.  As a reference for what stadiums are doing around Europe, the Champions League has opened up to 30% capacity. 
"Stadiums can be filled to a maximum of 30 per cent of capacity, except in cases where the local limit is lower. [Sept 24] Around 15,000 fans were present in the 67,000-capacity Puskas Arena in Budapest as Bayern Munich beat Sevilla 2-1." [3] Again, even at 30% capacity, no PL stadium reaches 25,000. Then the question becomes: when will fans be allowed to enter stadiums without social distancing. This could happen due to testing, low transmission rate, and/or vaccine. With cold winter weather, I think transmission and cases will continue to be bad. Vaccine rollout will hopefully improve things in early 2021, but not before March 16 [fourth bucket]. If UK vaccine rollout follows US, then general population will start to get vaccines in April, but two doses take 4-6 weeks, so effectively wouldn't be until late May. Therefore, after May 24 most likely. [1] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1139730
[2] https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/54716149
[3] https://www.goal.com/en-us/news/can-fans-attend-champions-league-europa-league-matches-2020/o05sx2ezk5cu10ey45gelf74k
I was waiting for explicit acknowledgment of stricter rules come end of January. Got that today from the scientific advisor.

Recency bias but the U.K. shutdown and travel cancellations that are happening, are a clear sign that the worst of the virus has yet to be experienced, so extrapolating from that there will be very little chance of a PL game have 25K fans. Even is a unlikely scenario that things (infections, govt restriction) don’t get worse, they will still likely yo-yo even as they downtrend.

Reduced expectations for 16 March to 23 May 2021 due Tier 4 emergency lockdown related to new virus strains. This should delay efforts to bring more fans to games despite large scale testing and vaccine distributions in the first half of 2021.

March has some probability due primarily to a large seasonal decrease + increase in natural + vaccinated immunity decreasing the R rate.  Some minor prob new strain infects more but is less dangerous.
New restrictions look like they put back even controlled-venue restrictions.

Shifting probability distribution to 24 May 2021 and beyond as COVID rages on and many locales seem to be retreating from opening. I'm based in the US and given US holidays that England share (Christmas and New Years) which are are likely super spreader events, I sadly believe the COVID rates will continue raging for 1-2 months post NYE, and so for restrictions to be let up before May 24 to allow 25K fans, e.g. mass public congregating events including concerts (not to mention graduations, weddings, etc) seem unlikely. Giving 30% chance to happening before May 24.

THe UK recently began allowing fans into stadiums in areas with lower number of cases. As the vaccine begins to roll out in the UK, it is possible they could see increasing numbers at games in Q1. There is an outside chance that the UK could see larger crowds for the final weeks of the Premier league. However, it still appears the PL is on track for a return to larger crowds for next season.

Extremely unlikely before Dec 31st as many locales are reverting to no fans (London announced to Tier 3 today). Best bet is between Mar 15 and Near end of May, with before Mar 15 are next best chance given UK is moving fast with vaccines and likely will attempt
Some more aggressive “normalizing” experiments like return to mass public events.

Vaccination takes 28 days to give immunity. Relaxation of restrictions when the most vulnerable are all vaccinated, which really means 'immunised'. Gives a date of about end of January. At that point, we will see the effects of an open Christmas in the data and see whether MPs vote down the Tier system. I'm pessimistic on the data for what seems self-explanatory reasons. By then, we will probably have seen capacity increases via the Tier system but I'm forecasting minor increases in notional numbers.  Currently spectators are placed 1 per 9 seats. To meet 25,000, the whole stadium needs to be opened up with spectators in 1 per 2 seats (difficult even in a 1m distance situation). Implications for time slots, mass testing, monitoring etc. Lobbying looks like the only route through to policy changes: Premier League threatens the EFL agreement unless government allows fans back in large numbers.

Currently some are allowed in. This will gradually increase month on month. As the vaccine roles out most vulnerable will likely be vaccinated within six months which will give authorities more freedom to relax restrictions.

https://voxeu.org/article/spread-covid-19-and-attending-football-matches-england hile there is evidence that fans socially distance voluntarily, our findings suggest that the standard way in which fans congregate to attend matches can facilitate the spread of the virus, even if capacity utilisation in the stadium is low. Certainly, fans will need to act in a more cautious manner in future whilst attending matches. Government pilots to let fans back in had tentatively begun in England but have been hampered by national and local restrictions being introduced. If these pilots are to restart, they will need to be closely monitored to see whether spreading fans out across stadiums and timing of entry into the stadium can effectively prevent the spread of the virus spread. At the risk of overestimating the impact this type of paper could have on actual policymaking, at the very least it increases the probability that some evidence would surface of an uptick in cases/death related to some of the low-capacity reopenings we are currently seeing.
+5%points on "not before 24/5/21"

Hancock planning for restrictions to be lifted once the vulnerable have been vaccinated.  Lifted enough to allow 1 person per 2 seats in a stadium by the end of the season? Would the government be eyeing up the FA Cup final as a capacity crowd, as some sort of unifying national moment?

A Sunday at Anfield:
Liverpool FC home game on 06 December 2020
2,000 supporters (the first since March 2020)

Updating for passage of time. 1 Jan-15 Mar: -2
16 Mar-23 May: +1
>24 May: +1
Not this season. Social distancing will remain in place most of the year.
Vaccine roll out starting next week. Increase estimate of 16 March to 23 May probability.
£250m support agreement from Premier League and EFl. Could be a government sweetener for fan capacity increasing to fund the package. Slight adjustment earlier.

Manchester United have the largest capacity ground in the country and 25,000 equates to roughly 1/3 capacity. So essentially the question boils down to when will the Premier League allow 1/3 capacity at games. Current guidance is for 1000-2000 and is likely to remain the status quo until at least the spring. The 2021/22 season would likely begin before October 2020 though. Is it possible that 25,000 could be allowed back into grounds for this point. In Japan's J-League there have already been sporting events with ~50% capacity despite Covid still being an outstanding issue.  I think it is very possible although not likely given transport issues getting to grounds. I assign a 25% probability to this scenario. The next two windows are narrower, and I see it as less likely that restrictions would be eased during winter months should Covid remain an issue. I see only a relatively small chance that no game will see a 25,000 attendance before May 2021 as ultimately money talks and there will be severe pressure to at least trial such a scenario. Therefore I assign a relatively low 5% to the final scenario.

The current news cycle appears to put "a return to normalcy" towards Easter/early April for the UK. News sites tend to paint things more optimistically than it will end up turning out.  There is currently a lot of buzz around vaccine schedules so I will assign a base belief with the majority after May 24 (to account for distribution delays) and update in 2 weeks. There is always the possibility of an early  "vaccine stunt" where they fill a stadium full of vaccinated people for a game to increase population compliance to build morale.

The focus on Old Trafford has to be put to the side now that varying capacities by localised area are being allowed.  It now becomes about 
1) How do capacity allowances progress from here? 
2) Which Premier League areas will be moved to Tier 1?
3) What are their capacities? I'll look into this at weekend.

Increased likelihood of march to may option because of imminent availability of vaccines but not by much as theres still plenty of questions regarding the logistics of distribution of the vaccines making large scale events doubtful till late spring at the earliest.

Reduced early options. Inconceivable before Christmas, and the chances are there is going to be another surge and T3 post the holidays. The only chance I see before March is some sort of charity event where vaccinated key workers are given tickets.
March-May is possible perhaps if citywide testing works and there is a big drop in numbers. However, the problem is there are few stadiums big a enough to get 25k in whilst adhering to social distancing - the only way I see it happening is if people are vaccinated, and given the proposed rollout approach, you are looking at that being some time off.

https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-55118467
PM plans for normal life by April, as a way to appease rebels on Tuesday's vote. Says that Tier system can be removed in February if voted for.  I'm still concerned about the Christmas spread, which will show in the 2021 Week 3 and Week 4 data.

I'm going to add a percentagepoint for the following: * Farfetched but not crazy: how about a premier league game played out abroad? Open xmas will push up rates into January which, for many football stadium areas, will push areas into Tier 2 (2000 fans max.). Tier reviews, I understand, are every three weeks. That takes us into February earliest. Old Trafford is the likely place to see 25,000 first for Premier League if capacity restrictions are loosened across the whole league at the same time. But Manchester is likely to stay in Tier 3 in December and, if Xmas is as bawdy as expected, will be in Tier 3 by end of January. As stated earlier, 2m distance in Old Trafford brings capacity down to about 9000-10000 (removing about 8 seats around each person). Even 1m distance would remove about 5 seats per person bringing capacity to about 12,500. The only hope for 25000 is mass testing; a system for tracking and proving; and enough people willing to attend. I'm a United fan but I recognise that many of our attendees are foreign visitors and/or from around the country! I have my eyes peeled for the results of Liverpool's mass testing project. Maybe they pilot opening Anfield as an extension of the project?

https://www.google.com/amp/s/www.skysports.com/amp/football/news/11095/12140319/coronavirus-fans-to-be-allowed-into-stadiums-in-england-at-end-of-lockdown Tier 1 areas allowed up to 4k fans (if capacity is over 8k) through December. Vaccine rollout and necessary review period leads well into Spring.  Grounds would need, Old Trafford specifically, ~30% capacity allowed initially to meet the 25k. However, a 2m distance rule in Old Trafford removes roughly 8-10 seats for every one attendee so 30% capacity remains a huge challenge.

22 November 2020 - Revision to forecast in light of recent vaccine developments, and NHS draft plan. NHS draft plan indicates a desire to vaccinate the majority of adults by mid-March. No mention of vaccines used or how logistical challenge overcome (particularly of note with the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine). The draft plan relies also on 7 million doses being available in December to start preparations. Still awaiting any vaccine to be approved for use. But as of now there are four either awaiting approval in late phase 3. Even if the entire adult (willing) population is vaccinated by the middle of March, there will need to be a review period, this would take at least three to four weeks, to gather and publish data. That's mid-April before social distancing could conceivably be relaxed completely. Without relaxing social distancing no premier league ground can hold +25,000 socially distanced spectators (Old Trafford, the largest, falls short by >1,000), although reducing it to 1m would help, but I believe the 2m rule makes sense because it puts others out of arms reach. I should also point out that social distancing in stadiums is one thing, ensuring those fans are not squeezed like sardines onto buses and trains and tubes getting to and from the grounds is another matter altogether. This likely the reason why on Monday 23rd November a 4,000 cap was announced on outdoor sports attendances under the new tier system, rather than a percentage-based system or whatever clubs say they can social distance. The reasoning is that 4,000 people moving to and from a specific location at about the same time should be able to be soaked up by the transportation system without overwhelming it. There would enormous lines outside train stations and it would likely take hours and hours to get them home without a cap on attendance numbers. Or there would be gridlock on the roads around the stadium if people chose to drive. Increasing the probability of 16/03/21 - 23/05/2021 event to 12%, reducing after 24/05/21 to 88%. I have read suggestions around allowing +25,000 fans into stadiums if they can prove their vaccination status, and thus not be required to be socially distanced. I cannot see a policy like that being ok'd because it would exclude those who wish to be vaccinated, but have not had the opportunity. Hence, all other probabilities remain at zero.

Shifting around a little, in my mind, with the vaccines starting to roll out, there is the potential for various relaxing of restrictions. Still early days, but happy being overall more "optimistic" on timing than the consensus, given it does seem the vaccine roll out will start early 2021, albeit it seems unlikely there will be 100% coverage by 24th May, it may allow reducing restrictions as at risk populations are covered.

Good vaccine news but near term the virus is widespread. While there is likely fatigue when it comes to locking down, it’s hard to imagine any responsible policy maker allowing this type of event to happen.

flue season so if not before december then not before march: split both
i guess it could happen before end of may, if only just for one game in a huge stadion? (not stadion is big enough to social distance 25k people though) so small change
Haven't got enough doses, as stated by other current social distancing regulations mean 25k not possible.

Current obstacles to overcome with mass testing:
- Liverpool Council is still running the pilot scheme for effectiveness. There have been no conclusions drawn yet. Notably, there is no information on the types of people submitting themselves to a test, which obviously influences the positive rates. A football crowd's positive rates could be very different.
- Similarly, there is no information on invalid tests and what the process is in the case of an invalid test.
- Liverpool's city-wide mass testing capacity, with the 20mins 'pregnancy style' test, is currently 50,000 per day. Football clubs will have a couple of hours before the game to test their crowd - imagine the infrastructure, workforce and expense that entails.
- Liverpool Council have so far managed to test ~23,000 with 150 positive cases. It is clear that football clubs would have to test over 25,000 because some will test positive which means (1) they cannot attend the game and (2) their mates they arrived with cannot attend the game. (https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/explainers-54872039) No doubt with the rapid testing being piloted, football clubs will want it rolled out as soon as possible but >25,000 looks aspirational with current numbers and pilots.

Manchester United have said about 23,500 fans can be safely accommodated in Old Trafford under the current social distance guidelines. As such, it appears that no Premier League teams stadium is large enough to seat +25,000 under current guidelines. No vaccine approved as yet, even with the approval of the current closet candidate, not enough doses for a large enough chunk of the population to suggest social distancing will not still be in force by summer 2021. Wembley appears to be capable of seating 28,000 socially distanced fans. I think there is a chance that the 2021 FA Cup final might be watched by +25,000 fans. Wembley Stadium could potentially seat 28,000 using a multiple derived from Old Trafford's reduction in capacity for Social Distancing.

Updated on the news that the Premier League is working with the UK government to figure out a route back for fans if a vaccine proves effective. Current government prediction is rolling out the vaccine starting in December, with England planning a rate of 1,000 vaccinations per GP surgery per week.  Assuming 3 GPs per surgery (based on my GP surgery) and 179 GPs registered in Manchester, I'd expect Manchester to deliver 40-60,000 vaccinations per week from January (giving time for ramping up from 0). I've chosen Manchester as Old Trafford is the first stadium under a percentage model to get to 25,000 available seats (besides Wembley Stadium, which no team uses for fixtures currently).  Roll that across the region, and you get a larger group of people able to buy tickets. Assuming that tickets can only be bought by people within Manchester, getting enough vaccines that 25,000 people can go to Old Trafford should be done by the Liverpool game in May.

Assuming the economic clout of the Premier League, I doubt the government will let it get to a full calendar year since fans were last allowed in stadiums (they already let fans into non-league grounds before the present lockdown).  It's proper in this instance to assume that stadiums will open at a percentage of maximum capacity to allow social distancing. Then it becomes a question of "At what percentage does a single Premier League stadium get at least 25,000 seats available?" Old Trafford, with a total capacity of 75.731, has 24,991 seats at 33% capacity, and 25,749 seats at 34% capacity. Old Trafford typically sells out for Premier League fixtures, with few away fans. If fans do stay away once stadiums reopen, the latest I'd expect Old Trafford to reach 25,000 tickets sold and fans in seats would be their match against Liverpool on 1st of May. Because I feel easing on restrictions will happen before 23rd March, I'm somewhat confident we'll see 25,000 fans at Old Trafford no later than the Liverpool fixture.  If we get to 50% capacity, there are 7 stadiums that can hold at least 25,000 spectators, reaching 19 of 20 if restrictions are fully lifted (Turf Moor has a capacity below 25,000).

Slightly adjusting my scores as I believe the recent vaccine news adds a slight improvement in the chances of the event happening earlier than May 24th.  The FA has made preparations and given the green light could move quickly to reinstate a level of stadium attendance.  Still likely to be late Winter (Feb) before this happens so the chance of this event happening pre March 15th is low, however I think it is most likely to happen between Mar 15 and May 24
England continues to struggle with the virus and there is no discussion about even beginning to plan for this many fans to be in attendance this season.

Ross County in Scotland given permission for 300 fans while they are in Tier 1 (https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/54818083).  Very very minor experiment for the 25k question but probably worth keeping a track of. No change to forecast right now.

No change in my position, given that England is going into lock-down from the 5th November for a least a month, makes it even more unlikly  that the Premier League will allow such a large group into their stadia by May 24.

Rapid testing is being rolled out. PM reckons that they will have city-wide rapid testing available at some point before the spring. Equally, his comments during briefing today were extremely optimistic re:spring situation. Maybe that is empty reassurance, maybe it isn't.  Regardless, I think the national lockdown now pushes back any 'fans in stadiums' discussions way beyond Christmas.  As stated, when they do happen, Old Trafford could test up to 23,500 capacity with rapid testing but you can read my last post on forecasting timeframes for that.

Covid cases are at all-time highs in England right now and they are unlikely to go down much over the winter. While ticket sales mean money the lawsuits and safety issues associated with getting people into the stands prematurely simply isn't worth the risk. It will likely take months for them to phase in enough fans to a single stadium to meet this criteria and that will only begin once cases have gone down from where they are perched right now. Ultimately, I think fans will be allowed back into the stadiums en masse come next season. Before then, it'll be mostly empty seats and authorized personnel only.

We appear to be a long way from having fans in grounds in England - any fans this year seems practically impossible.
In addition, Manchester United have recently proposed a COVID-19 capacity of ~23,500. This is by some way the largest club ground in the PL, and whilst Old Trafford is aging and may be less easily converted to appropriate distancing measures, this still represents less than a third of the standard capacity. As such it seems unlikely even the newer, though smaller stadiums are going to manage to get closer to half full (e.g. the other three 60,000 seater stadiums would be 40% capacity).
In addition, I imagine significantly smaller volumes of spectators will be allowed in initially, and several weeks of evaluation to determine if attending games results in spikes of cases. At present, COVID cases are going in the wrong direction - opening up football stadiums is far from governments minds. I will re-evaluate in the new year, or when a vaccine is found.

She is arguing for stadiums to be reopened with staggered arrival and temperature checks: https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/54716149 This number capacity would have to run for at least a month to measure its impact on rates before they consider higher capacities. In terms of timeline: Let's say Man U get the go ahead for 23,000 in January (after xmas chaos), it would be the start of March before rates have been tracked and analysed. A decision to increase would then be made for mid-March / April at the earliest.

After listening to Dr Fauci on Andrew Marr this morning. I'm shifting more into the future.

Average attendances for 2019/20 seasons show that only 12 of the 20 teams averaged over 25,000 per game with full capacity allowance and no coronavirus (PL: https://www.worldfootball.net/attendance/eng-premier-league-2019-2020/1/; Ch: https://www.worldfootball.net/attendance/eng-championship-2019-2020/1/). That means, roughly, only 3/5ths of the games played in any given time period will have the chance of being over 25,000 with full capacity allowance. Man U's average attendance was 58,000 last season. Earlier in the month, a few of us were considering the potential for 33% capacity allowance and concluded that only Man U and Wembley were viable possibilities. However, not accounting for the deterrent of the virus and economic hardship, a 33% capacity would dwindle Man U's average attendance to <20,000; meanwhile, Wembley does not host premier league games so that's completely out of the question. That leads me to believe that the only chance this has before the end of the 2020/21 season is if the premier league manages to successfully trial mass, rapid testing of fans outside stadiums. These tests are being trialled at Heathrow Airport but take an hour for results, and cost £80. Boris said last week that they are trialling rapid tests that take 'as little as 15 minutes' and I heard on the radio that the premier league's supplier has its hands on them as well. These tests are being trialled in the community this month (https://news.sky.com/story/coronavirus-millions-of-15-minute-covid-tests-being-developed-for-uk-says-pm-12105931). Even still, Man U would need permission for at least 45% capacity, based on averages; stocks of 15 minute tests; to organise the testing of over 25,000 fans pre-match and ascertain 25,000 negative results; and all of this, likely, after a trial period on limited capacity and waiting for the results of affects on infection rates. This pushes me beyond "before 15 March 2021".

The development of 15min tests by the Premier League's chosen coronavirus testing company could alter the course of this. 25,000 is still a big number to get through the turnstiles except in the largest stadiums.

Boris Johnson said a few weeks ago that the current Covid restrictions could last 6 months in the UK. that takes us to March. I find it unlikely that stadiums will be allowed to host tens of thousands of people under such circumstances. Especially given the second wave of Covid cases in the UK. in the first wave it took until September before even a few stadiums were allowed to trial a few thousand visitors and this was quickly halted as the Covid outbreak accelerated. So even when the Covid outbreak is brought under control it will be some time before large number of people are allowed into stadiums.  To enable social distancing stadiums will need to remain below capacity. At 1/3rd capacity even Old Trafford would be below 25k visitors. In other words 25k is a lot of people in the current environment. I think 50% capacity wouldn't be allowed for some time. There are 7 teams with stadiums larger than 50k that would result in the 25k target being achieved if 50% capacity was allowed. All of those 7 teams are in areas where the worst outbreaks in the UK are located (all are in cities / regions that are tier 2 or higher restrictions). I have seen comments below about the financial difficulties of the clubs at the bottom of the prem if stadiums remain closed. I don't think this is a consideration for premier league clubs as most revenue comes from the TV licencing deals (just look at how much the premier league spent on transfers in the transfer window).
Maybe 10% chance of a vaccine by Early February which would mean roll out by March was possible. A bit higher in time for May.

BBC includes a lot of quotation from Culture Sec, Dowden (https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/54539010). There is an unquoted "Crowds may not come back until the end of March at the earliest" with no explanation as to where that thought comes from. Regardless, Dowden is taking a very firm and fair approach in his dealings with the media over football. Dowden reports to The S*n suggest that plans are being put in place so that stadiums will know exactly how to open up safely with Covid guidelines. There is some mention of a taskforce that includes research from Prof. John Van-Tam regarding stadiums and mitigating measures (https://www.thesun.co.uk/news/12839745/oliver-dowden-football-fans-back-in-grounds-soon/). I've flipped my bias to later in the year - when flu season has completely disappeared - and leveled out slightly given that plans are being researched and debated ready for an 'open on command' towards the end of the season.

Initial prediction based on EPL 1,000 rule being pushed back from October and the increasing rates in certain areas of the country. It seems to go without saying, on first thought, that the government would not want this to happen during Winter while they strive to protect the NHS.  As noted by @mkaa_london, there are talks of 30% capacity in some grounds as a starting point which leaves Old Trafford and Wembley. But (1) Old Trafford is in a hotspot currently; and (2) Wembley does not host Premier League games. However, it is hard to see how a Premier League season is financially viable without 25,000 fans having visited a stadium especially for clubs at the lower end of the table. The government and FA will have to dip their toe at some point.  Will update at weekend when I have done some reading around.

Projections from the Institute for Health Metrics (IHME) show that the easing of mandates from today (12 Oct 2020) will take the daily infections count well past the first peak in the UK. The government are unlikely to ease restrictions through the winter months to relieve pressure on the NHS to enable other non-Covid related treatments take place.  EPL spectator plans have been pushed back from October to allow 1,000 fans to enter: https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/0/when-football-fans-return-back-covid-sports-stadiums-reopen/ There is discussion of 30% capacity at some grounds. Old Trafford and Wembley Stadium are the only 2 grounds that could accommodate 25,000 under that rule.
A vaccine won’t available to the larger public before may 2021. Only with large scale and stable vaccination programs in place, countries will feel its safe to allow such large gatherings

UEFA will allow home fans up to 30% capacity from next week starting at the international break.  This is subject to local laws but does indicate a potential move to test fan attendance at European football matches.  This could well be a precursor to implementation in the premier league so the results of any large scale trials will help inform likely future timelines.

If similar trends continue over winter (no major second wave but sustained infection) then seems impossible Government would want to jeopardise Christmas. Slight chance of a return in early 2021 if c-19 controlled over Winter. Seems more likely next May onwards when vaccine/testing picture is clearer.

First, we are unlikely to have any vaccine available to the general public before Spring of next year. Even potential vaccines being prepped now are slated to go public in the Summer. Second, once a vaccine is widely available, it is almost impossible to see the Premier League being a top priority for true reopenings. There are not tests available that would be practical for game attendees and the liabilities of allowing thousands of fans into a game that may or may not have been immunized or have the virus is huge. Moreover, fans have already become accustomed to the current state of things and while they will expect the games to return to normal at some point it is unlikely enough will demand we get back to business before the season's end to put any real pressure on the EPL or British government, especially as we are perhaps at the beginning of a second wave even today.

return of fans on a large scale is not likely until a vaccine is generally available. winter months may see more covid cases and no vaccine. possible in the spring given potential for herd immunity/vaccine/treatment development but unlikely that governments will be swift to reopen sporting events that are seen as super spreading events.

As of now, with no vaccine likely before the end of the year, it remains nearly impossible to see a stadium with 25,000 fans in the UK. Even games with the Premier Leagues' most popular teams, for example, Liverpool, Chelsea, Tottenham, 25,000 would still be nearly at 50% capacity. The long hold out, and a possible source of optimism, is Old Trafford. With a capacity of nearly 75,000 attendance of 25,000 would be only 33%, which still seems high. Additionally, with the UK seeing increases in numbers and shelving plans for limited fan attendance in the coming weeks, it seems unlikely to see attendance levels anywhere close.  The possibility of a vaccine being produced for large scale production in Q1 2021 leaves open a slight chance of larger gatherings in the mid-March to mid-May timeframe. However, given that would represent only the last few match week's of the season, the league may look for the 2021-2022 season for higher attendance levels. Thus, the 98% likelihood of a post 24MAY2021 for the 25,000 attendance levels.
US announcing significant mass-testing capabilities, thinking this may accelerate things.
25,000 is a high hurdle. A lot depends upon widespread uptake of a vaccine which is a long way off.
Slight adjustment due to the possibility of a vaccine seeming slightly higher and the accompanying reduction in restrictions and lockdowns.

The current environment doesn't lend itself to having everyone come back. Currently Europe is experiencing a second wave of Covid. Current soccer games are either being called or played with no fans (as opposed to some football and other sports in the US, except basketball). Also, while the Spanish Flu killed more people, if you look at the sporting events at the time, most of the fans were not attending these sporting events either.

Further to my initial forecast I have now considered, based on other comments that it would only take around a 30% attendance allowance for some clubs to hit the 25K mark, and with that  the probability of the forecast occurring earlier has increased a little. I read a BBC article yesterday which points out that the actual number of COVID cases are much lower than during the March outbreak (Increased testing is resulting in a higher number of confirmed cases however a lack of testing in March/April resulted in most reported case numbers coming from hospital admissions thus not giving an accurate number of actual cases or useful comparison).  The current lower number of hospital admissions and deaths supports the theory that the second wave is not yet a concrete occurrence but figures over the next 3-4 weeks will help clarify.  This has made me feel a little more optimistic about the potential for 25k attendance to happen 16th March and 23 May so have tweaked my scores accordingly.
if enough Britons are vaccinated by summer 2021, things will start returning to normal
Belgium claiming they'll be first and potentially available by March.

As of 23 Sep, only 20-30% of maximum capacity are allowed in certain stadiums.  The average attendance is 38,000 fans so unless the 1 meter social distance rule is lifted, we won't see 25K fans back in stadiums.  Given the cold and flu season, the current limited attendance policy will likely hold through the end of winter.  There will be pressure come early Spring to increase attendance so 25K is likely as limits to attendance are lifted as the weather warms and a COVID vaccine circulates.

Seems like before the end of the year is very unlikely: https://www.express.co.uk/sport/football/1338578/Premier-League-news-Boris-Johnson-UK-government-football-fans-empty-stadiums-coronavirus They would need 30-40% capacity at some of the bigger stadiums (Old Trafford, Emirates, Hotspur) to get to the 25,000 number. Well it looks like the country will be some type of lock down, with minimum size crowds for the next six months, so its very unlikely to be large crowds at any premiership match until this time next year.

Shifted 4% from Jan - Mar period to May.  I do not think it's just whether there will be (enough doses of) a vaccine by April.  Most important factor is how 25,000 can reach the stadium, disperse accordingly to their seats and leave once the match is over while adhering to safety measures.

Trial fixtures with 1000 fans have just been cancelled due to increasing numbers of COVID cases. Social distancing measures have been increased such as shutting pubs at 10pm and the rule of 6, however case numbers are now exponential with an R rate over 1.  It is to be seen whether these measures alone are sufficient and it is possible that cases will continue to rise leading to further lockdown and not less.  Also this situation is unlikely to abate over the winter months and a vaccine will most likely not be available on sufficient scale to conduct a nationwide vaccine programme till next year.  As a result the probability of at least  25k fans attending a premier league this year are highly remote.  A vaccine development this year, the commencement of spring, or a reduction in case numbers could result in the potential for a 25k+ match to be held towards the end of Q1.  Although nearing the end of the season clubs generate significant revenue from stadium attendance and there will be immense pressure to accommodate stadium capacities if a change in situation warrants.

This is more of a proxy forecast about when an effective vaccine will become widely available. I agree wholeheartedly with @oddball 8's research. If anything, I think he (and we) are mostly too optimistic about when a vaccine will be provided to the general public (after healthcare workers, pre-existing conditions etc.).

Before the "second wave" started, UK Government seemed perfectly happy to open a lot of stuff up without a vaccine. Until today, there were plans for attendance at games starting in October. [1] Those plans have since been scrapped. If the second wave comes and goes quite quickly, I can see a big push to get crowds back in ASAP. Though, with flu season around the corner I'd be surprised if the UK shakes this wave quickly enough for stadium attendance to be back at all in 2020, let alone to the levels needed for this question to be resolved. Boris Johnson has said that the latest restrictions will likely be in place for 6 months, which takes us to past March. [2] @Averroes did the calculations and found that stadium attendance would need to be up to half capacity before this question is met. The trial attendance undertaken at the Amex was 2500 people [3]. We'd need ten times as many to be allowed in for this question to be met. With a one metre social distancing rule, it's estimated that you'd be able to get attendance up to about 30 percent [3].  To allow for stadium attendance without social distancing, you'd need either a) mass testing to guarantee that attendees were negative b) very low case rates c) a vaccine. At the moment, cases are high (4000+ a day) and testing is hard to come by. A vaccine available to the British public would be the silver bullet to resume full stadium attendance. Optimistic estimates have a vaccine being delivered in the New Year, with most estimates at more like Spring 2021. [4] In my pessimistic estimation, I have also accounted for the possibility that the season will be abandoned or postponed for a long time. We're already seeing teams weakened through having positive cases among their core squad (Laporte at City, for example). A combination of increased injuries due to a crowded match schedule and a number of players out with covid at any given moment might seriously deplete the number of healthly players in the league. Additionally, if the situation gets much worse in the UK, the Government might postpone the league (like they did in March) as part of a second lockdown.  [1] https://metro.co.uk/2020/09/22/plans-for-fans-at-premier-league-games-and-other-sporting-events-in-october-paused-13306131/

[4] https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-51665497#:~:text=Researchers%20hope%20to%20achieve%20the,no%20guarantees%20it%20will%20work.

It previously took 3 months to reduce to about 500 cases/day from this point in the curve in the first wave/spike, which rules out 2020. In the unlikely event the UK takes a stance on Sars-Cov-19 similar to Australia, they would need to reduce daily numbers into the low double digits before considering crowds of this size. While it's a possibility, I don't think BoJo has the economic principals or stomach to undergo what has happened in Victoria over the last 2 months (https://www.9news.com.au/national/coronavirus-victoria-update-11-new-cases-covid19-2-deaths-latest-numbers-dhhs/0a66e26a-b6a9-4538-abc2-0a81d69be076), which has undergone a full lock-down because of double digit growth in cases.

With a new wave surge of Covid-19 cases in England likely peaking in October, I think this year is done. When stadiums start to allow fans, social distancing means there will be a maximum capacity of 33%. The biggest capacity in the Premier League is Old Trafford (Manchester United) with 74,879 seats. Divided by 3 = 24,960.  There is currently no live audience in England but Germany is allowing a limited amount of fans [1]:
"Six out of the nine host teams were allowed to welcome supporters on the first matchday of the season, with the number of spectators ranging from 4,600 to 9,300, filling 10 to 25% of the stadium seats." Due to the rising levels of transmission in England and the closeness to Winter - a time which increases pressure on the health service anyway - I think the same social distancing measures will stay in place until at least Jan 1, 2021.  Cases are expected to rise during Winter so dropping these measures seems unlikely in the first few months of 2021 as well.  After/around March time, it seems more likely that more fans will be allowed into stadiums. But this is dependant on case numbers. Using other European countries as a measure will be useful as they have been slightly ahead of England so far on a similar-looking graph. The Premier League season is set to end on May 23, 2021. The Euros start just after the end of the season and their rules may also have an impact on domestic decisions. Only 1 stadium can not hold more than 25,000 people in the Premier League - Turf Moor (Burnley).  [1] https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/54229045

Second wave here now. I have a hard time seeing large gatherings being allowed this year.  Some small scale tests are run right now with around a 1000 in attendance.[1] There will likely be some kind of push for a larger attendance to be allowed. @kerryb has written a post about at which percentage stadiums can take in 25 000 or more in attendance.[2] My initial hunch it that the pandemic will run through UK until the new year is here and then so many will have had the disease that it will slow its spread the first half of next year. This will make it possible to open stadiums at 50% capacity somewhere between 1 January to 23 May. Still see not before 24 May as a big possibility. 1. https://www.bbc.com/sport/54158891
2. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1136558

Before Oct. 19, 2020: Given the current statistics of COVID-19 cases in the UK as of September 19, it is unlikely that the stadiums will be able to receive large numbers of fans in the short term. "The UK reported 4,422 new daily cases of coronavirus on Saturday, 100 more new cases than on Friday and the highest daily total since 8 May. (https://www.theguardian.com/world/live/2020/sep/19/coronavirus-live-news-trump-pledges-vaccine-for-all-by-april-as-melbourne-faces-more-protests) Between 19 Oct. 2020-31 Dec. 2020: With the coming of colder temperatures and the flu season, people will likely be encouraged to remain at home more. Between 1 Jan. 2021-March 2021: After the Christmas Holidays, there most likely will have been many family and social gatherings, which means that there is a possibility of further community spread of COVID-19. Therefore, measures to curb a potential rising of the curve would be in place.   Between 16 March 2021-23 May 2021: There is a higher potential that a vaccine or other treatments for COVID-19 will be available.  Not before 24 May 2021: This is a more likely scenario when it comes to a potential vaccine or treatment that would allow more people to gather in public spaces.

I believe that much of the timing of this depends on the timing of Covid-19 Vaccine as well as the ability to distribute this  vaccine efficiently.  Additionally, as we've already been seeing a rise in infections in the UK and more talk of being aggressive in managing the virus.  With that in mind, I think that it's highly unlikely for us to have heavily attended soccer matches during the 2020-2021 Premier League season. Additionally, if you look at the largest stadium in the premier league, it's Old Trafford Stadium, where Manchester United plays.  This stadium holds roughly 75,000 people, and if you assume they go to quarter capacity, that means only roughly 19,000 fans.
COVID19 is building up again flu and colds is going to confound the whole thing and despite the football fanatics wanting it an Boris wanting to be popular, this cannot happen.

- The PL needs fans in stadiums to make money so there will be an honest push to make it happen this season
- Arsenal will attempt fans on Oct 3 but the new spike in COVID cases in the UK puts this at risk - bellweather game
- Talk is allowing 20 - 30% maximum when fans return to stadiums - a one metre requirement between fans
- There are no stadiums large enough to handle 25,000 fans at a 30% capacity
- There is only one stadium (Man U's) that can handle 25,000 fans at a 35% capacity
- There are only 7 teams that have stadiums large enough to have 25,000 fans at a 50% capacity, keeping in mind that stadium staff has to be factored in which potentially limits Liverpool, Man City and Newcastle from allowing 25,000 fans at a 50% capacity So, the question is, when will the PL allow 50% capacity?  I can't see it happening this year when BJ is today talking about closing or limiting bars and restaurants again. Then, will it happen before the end of the season?  I have to place some chance that it won't.  So, starting at 0%, 0%, 25%, 50%, 25% Go Magpies!
